title: Sleep and Health
transcript: We spend about one third of our lives sleeping, yet many of us don't prioritize it. Sleep is when your body repairs itself and your brain processes information from the day. Poor sleep affects everything – mood, concentration, immune function, even weight. Adults need seven to nine hours per night, but quality matters as much as quantity. To improve sleep quality, maintain a consistent schedule. Going to bed and waking up at the same time – even on weekends – regulates your body clock. Avoid screens before bed; blue light disrupts the production of melatonin, the sleep hormone. Keep your bedroom cool, dark, and quiet. Limit caffeine after noon and alcohol before bed – both interfere with sleep cycles. If you can't fall asleep within twenty minutes, get up and do something relaxing until you feel drowsy. Lying awake creates anxiety. Chronic sleep problems deserve medical attention. Don't accept poor sleep as normal. Quality rest is not a luxury – it's a necessity for physical and mental health.
